title: Best Portable Games on Mobile to Help the Commute Back into the Office
description: Best Portable Games on Mobile to Help the Commute Back into the Office

text: It's happening. Finally, many parts of the world are starting to return to some form of "normality," and with that, many of us will inevitably begin to return to the office with actual real people, instead of a dozen virtual calls a day. Travelling to events and scheduling meetups with colleagues or potential business partners can actually happen now too!

A big part of this is the actual commute, whether that's via car, bus, train, plane or whatever. This downtime allows handheld gaming to shine. Why not plug into your Samsung Galaxy Buds2 Samsung Galaxy Buds2 - and be immersed in a world while arguably not in the most fun of environments, these experiences can turn what feels like a full afternoon of impatiently waiting for your destination, into a "wow, we're already there" outcome.

Designed to be worn all day, it even features Active Noise Cancellation to truly immerse yourself and block out all unwanted sounds, such as commuters on trains. No need to worry about missing your stop either, as the Galaxy Buds2 offer three adjustable ambient sound levels.

Of course, to do that you need to know what the best games are to play on the go. So, here's a selection of mobile games that are well worth your time and will (hopefully) help combat any fears surrounding getting back to the office.

Action RPGs don't come much bigger than this. Genshin Impact from MiHoYo set the gaming world on fire when it launched in September 2020, balancing its stunning open-world environment with a compelling battle system. Taking inspiration from The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild, the animation style is perfectly suited to mobile devices, while the world of Teyvat is easy to get absorbed by.

Furthermore, Genshin Impact balances its free-to-play aspects well, for the most part, something many others on the platform still struggle with. Winning numerous awards and generating more than $1 billion in revenue in less than a year, Genshin Impact is one of the best examples of the capabilities of what mobile can do.

Many popular console mascots try to make their transition to mobile and ultimately are tripped up by simply trying to port across the same experience. Not Crash Bandicoot though! No Candy Crush Developer King went all out for Crash Bandicoot: On the Run, creating a runner-like game that sees the loveable marsupial visit different dimensions to stop his nemesis, Dr Neo Cortex.

After going on to be downloaded more than eight million times in its opening 24 hours, King has continued to expand upon the levels and even bring in Spyro the Dragon for a special event. There's a lot to like here, if you can get past the sometimes overly obtrusive monetisation.

There's plenty of rhythm games out there but few capture the same excitement and buzz as Thumper. Players must hit notes on a series of single or multi-tracks that guides a beetle-like creature through numerous worlds exploding with great colour. Its awe-inspiring visuals aside, the soundtrack is as heart-pumping as you can get, only bettered by being locked in with a pair of headphones.

While the summer of 2016 will live on as that time Pokémon GO took over the world (and arguably the closest humanity has ever come to world peace), the game has only continued to grow. In fact, the worldwide catch 'em all experienced its best year ever in 2020 - an unthinkable achievement, considering much of the world was in lockdown and the game is designed around walking about outside.
There's also a fantastic community found in many towns and cities ready to embrace newcomers and returning players. Well worth jumping back to help get those daily steps in.

And what's better to experience these games than via the Galaxy Buds2, Samsung's smallest and lightest wireless earbuds to date. From now, you can also track down your Galaxy Buds2 with SmartThings Find the new saviour when in a pre-office rush!

Matthew Forde is a freelance journalist with work published across TechRadar, IGN, USgamer, Fandom, PocketGamer.biz and more. You can find him on Twitter @MattForde64 talking about all things tech, games and pop culture - particularly superheroes.
